What did early Canadian pioneer wives do?

A Questionnaire

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name Mrs. Elsie Dubman
Address Brockley, Sask., Box 17
Birthplace Bristol, England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? Near Brockley, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Manitoba & Toronto
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3
How far was it to your nearest store? 11 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, sugar, tea, rolled oats in cotton sacks,
and canned corn & beans, 4 peas, and lots of other things, tomatoes sometimes canned fruit if ours run short of any kind

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
Oak Lake flour and several other brands: Glencoe, Quaker
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 20 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 75¢
What other grain products did you use? Beans
Cornmeal? Some
Whole wheat flour? Home ground
Other? Corn Flakes & other breakfast cereals, shredded wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Some
How did you grind it? With the grain chopper
1910. Tubman, Elsie
293. Tubman, Elsie
Box 17,
Brooklyn.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ... well, we dug on school land across the road.

How far was this water from your home? ... almost a ¼ of a mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... always in barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In 1920 we dug another well on this farm and it is right near the house as we moved all the buildings near the water, it is across the road from the first well. We had another well for stock but it was not good for cooking, but this one here is a spring.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Sugar used to come in cotton sacks now it is in paper sacks and lots of other things are done up in paper. Flour for one and salt & rolled oats and small sacks of sugar are all paper now. Cheese used to come in 2 lb wooden boxes now they are cardboard. Raisins used to always be in bulk now they are in packages sometimes also dates & currants and cherries.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Oranges, porridge, oatmeal or Cream of Wheat, toast, cheese, eggs, 1910.

and either fruit or jelly. Butter, coffee & cream, milk.

Dinner: Pork fried, potatoes mashed, and either canned tomatoes or turnips or some other vegetables and either pudding or pie or fruit.

"Bread & Butter & tea & milk & cream."

Supper: Warmed potatoes or roasted ones and Bread & butter and cookies or cake and fruit and meat of some kind or fish.

Bread & Butter & tea & Xmas Cake

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

As I have a good head and 2 good hands and not afraid to use them, I have never been idle yet and I am getting to be an old woman and a widow for almost 12 years and had a sick husband for about 15 years.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Today there is a lot more salads used and a lot of people use more canned vegetables and fruit. They buy also bread, buns and cakes, doughnuts, and they buy celery and lettuce or cabbage in the winter.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In the last 10 years we buy sausages and all kinds of meat but the rest I make or prepare myself, bake bread and cakes, pies and cook vegetables and soups, and always make our own fruit but bought our honey. Sometimes buy canned soup in the summer so I have a small family. All the stores in Brooksby have an electric refrigerator.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In the early days I had cows and we both milked them and sometimes churned as much as a hundred lbs of butter a week and got about 35 to 50 dozen eggs a week, and packed the butter in big wooden butter tubs or pails and traded it at the store for groceries. The butter and eggs were both 15¢. In the first years we took them to Star City 11 miles in a wagon and brought back groceries in the wagon. Had quite a load—both ways as some of the neighbors had open and they would send with us or go with us and get their groceries too. You could get quite a lot of groceries then cheap for not much money. You could not get a cent of cash for eggs or butter except what I sold to bachelors around here and I baked bread for 4 to 6 bachelors the first 9 or 10 years till I got a big family of my own to bake and cook for folks around here.
Today there is a lot more calico used and a lot of people use more cotton. They buy also bread, flour and sugar in the winter.

In the last 10 years we buy less meat or purchase myself, but I still buy fruit, vegetables, eggs, and bread and order our own fruit but bought our honey and always make our own jam. The summer we have an electric refrigerator.

In the early days I had cows and we both milked them and sometimes churned as much as a hundred lbs of butter in a week and got about $3.50 to $5.00 per dozen eggs. We had a big wooden butter tub on the porch and the butter was kept in the tub. The butter was sold at 15 cents per pound.

We took them to Star City, Illinois in a wagon and brought back groceries in the wagon. We would send with us go with us and get their groceries too. You could get quite a bit of money by selling eggs and milk except what I needed to be able to buy food for my family. My family only came to town once a year.
